title: Identifying Red Flags in Scams
description: Learn to spot the warning signs that indicate a message might be a scam. These concepts apply to all scam types and tactics, so you can protect yourself no matter the circumstance.

sections.title: Introduction to Red Flags
sections.body: Let's learn how to spot scam messages. While the specific tricks change, most scams leave common clues – we call these 'red flags'. Recognizing these warning signs helps you stay safe and avoid costly mistakes, even with new types of scams. This module will show you exactly what to look for.

sections.title: Quick Test: Spot the Scam Signs
sections.body: Let's start with a quick challenge. Scammers often try to pressure you with urgent messages. See if you can spot the warning signs in this example.

interactionData.question:
Take a look at this text message:

> *'Message from IRS: You have unpaid taxes. To avoid penalties, submit your Social Security Number and payment method now: secure-irs-help.net.'*

Which of these are warning signs (red flags) in this message? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Asking for sensitive personal info (like SSN)
options.feedback: Good catch! Asking for info like your SSN or payment details via text is a major warning sign. Legitimate organizations, especially the IRS, won't do this.

options.text: Unexpected demand for money (claiming unpaid taxes)
options.feedback: You got it! An unexpected demand for money, especially combined with threats (like penalties), is a very common scam tactic.

options.text: Contains obvious spelling or grammar errors
options.feedback: Good observation - this *particular* message looks fairly well-written. While bad spelling/grammar *can* be a red flag in some scams, many scammers create very professional-looking messages now. So, correct spelling doesn't automatically mean it's safe!

options.text: Using official or professional-sounding language
options.feedback: Be careful with this one! Scammers often try hard to sound official or professional to gain your trust. Unfortunately, tone alone doesn't guarantee safety.

sections.title: Red Flag: Urgency
sections.body: Feel pressured to act right now by a message? That's a common scam tactic! Scammers create fake emergencies—using threats about fees, legal action, or locked accounts—hoping you'll react out of fear without thinking.

sections.title: Spot the Pressure Tactic
sections.body: Remember how scammers create fake emergencies to rush you? They use threats and tight deadlines hoping you'll act fast without thinking. Let's see how well you can spot this pressure tactic in action.

interactionData.question: Read these messages. Which one uses fake urgency or pressure *most* aggressively?

options.text: Your package will be delivered tomorrow between 2-5pm.
options.feedback: This sounds like a typical delivery update. It gives information but doesn't pressure you to do something immediately.

options.text: Your Amazon account password will expire in 7 days. Please update it at your convenience.
options.feedback: Good thinking. While there's a deadline here (7 days), it's presented reasonably and asks you to update 'at your convenience' – not usually signs of a high-pressure scam.

options.text: URGENT: Your account will be PERMANENTLY DELETED in 1 HOUR if you don't verify now!
options.feedback: Exactly! The all caps 'URGENT,' the extreme threat ('PERMANENTLY DELETED'), and the impossibly short deadline ('1 HOUR') are classic high-pressure scam tactics designed to make you panic.

options.text: Your monthly statement is now available. Please review it by the end of the month.
options.feedback: Right, this looks like a standard notification. A deadline like 'end of the month' generally gives plenty of time to act without feeling intense pressure.

sections.title: Red Flag: Too Good To Be True
sections.body: See an offer promising free prizes, easy money, or huge investment returns? **Hit pause.** Scammers dangle tempting bait like this hoping your excitement will make you click before you think. While great deals exist, truly unbelievable offers (like guaranteed 100%+ returns or unexpected big prizes) are almost always scams. Trust your gut: if it sounds too good to be true, it probably is.

sections.title: Real Deal or Fake Bait?
sections.body: Now let's practice separating exciting (but fake) offers from potentially real ones. Look at the messages below – some are likely scams trying to trick you, while others might be legitimate communications. Drag each message to the category where you think it belongs.

dragItems.text: Message: 'Respond now! Claim your free iPhone before supply runs out!'
Ad: 'You may be eligible for 0% financing for 72 months on a new Nissan. Call your local Nissan dealer for more info.'
Text: 'Congratulations! You've been selected as a winner of the $5,000 grand prize. Reply Y now to claim!'
Notification: 'Your monthly statement is ready. Log in to view and manage your account.'
Message: 'This new crypto platform guarantees 100-200% returns on your investment! Interested?'

sections.title: Red Flag: Requests for Payment
sections.body: Getting pressured to pay a fee or send money right away? That's a big warning sign! Scammers use different tricks to get your money before you realize it's a scam. Tap the sections below to learn about common payment scams.

expandableItems.title: Paying to Get a 'Prize'?
expandableItems.content:
The scam: You're told you've won something (a prize, lottery, grant) but first you must pay a fee, tax, or shipping cost to 'unlock' it. 
**The reality:** There's no prize. That fee goes straight to the scammer. Legitimate prizes don't require you to pay upfront.

expandableItems.title: Getting 'Overpaid'?
expandableItems.content:
The scam: Someone 'accidentally' sends you too much money (often via check or payment app) for something you're selling or doing, and asks you to refund the difference. 
**The reality:** Their original payment is fake or will bounce later. After you send the 'extra' money back, their payment fails, and you've lost the money you sent.

expandableItems.title: Fake Emergency or Official?
expandableItems.content:
The scam: Someone contacts you pretending to be:
* A loved one in sudden trouble needing emergency cash.
* An official (IRS, police, utility co.) demanding payment to avoid arrest, fines, or service shutoff.
**The reality:** They're faking the identity and the crisis. **Always verify** independently before sending money, especially if contacted unexpectedly. Call your loved one or the organization directly using a known number, not one provided in the message.

sections.title: Red Flag: Requests for Personal Information
sections.body: Got an unexpected text or call asking for details like your Social Security or bank account number? Pause. Scammers often create fake urgency or tempting offers. Real businesses rarely ask for sensitive info out of the blue.

sections.title: Spot the Phishing Bait!
sections.body: You know to **Pause** before sharing info. Why? Because scammers *want* details like your SSN or passwords to access accounts or steal your identity. Remember, real businesses rarely text asking for sensitive data out of the blue. Let's practice spotting the danger!

interactionData.question: Put your scam-spotting skills to the test! Which text message is most likely fishing for your personal info?

options.text: Text message says: "Please rate your recent customer service experience from 1-5 stars."
options.feedback: Good thinking! This asks for an opinion, not sensitive details. While often safe, being cautious about unexpected texts is always smart. You're building good habits!

options.text: Text message says: "To verify your identity, please reply with your Social Security Number and date of birth."
options.feedback: Exactly! Asking for your SSN and birth date via text is a huge red flag. Real organizations won't do this. Spotting this difference is key to protecting yourself – nice work!

options.text: Text message says: "Click here to see your delivery status and estimated arrival time."
options.feedback: You're right, this doesn't *ask* for info here, but clicking unknown links can be risky! Trusting your gut if a link feels off is another great way to stay safe. Well spotted!

options.text: Text message says: "Reply YES to confirm your appointment for tomorrow at 2:00 PM."
options.feedback: That's correct! This is just asking for a simple confirmation, not private data. Recognizing low-risk requests helps you focus on the real threats. Keep practicing!

sections.title: Red Flag: Unknown Number/Unexpected Message
sections.body: Get a text or call from a number you don't recognize? It's wise to pause. Responding, even to say 'stop', can sometimes signal to scammers that your number is active. If the message is truly important and legitimate, they'll likely leave a voicemail or find another way to reach you.

sections.title: Does the Message Make Sense?
sections.body: Okay, besides the number, look at the *message content*. Does it relate to something you actually did or use? Scammers often send fake alerts (about accounts you don't have) or bogus offers hoping you'll react quickly. Let's practice spotting messages that feel 'off'.

dragItems.text: Text: 'Your Netflix payment of $49.99 processed.' (But you don't have Netflix)
Text: 'Your Amazon order #A12345 shipped.' (And you did order recently)
Text: 'Your Chase card shows a $500 Best Buy charge.' (You have Chase & shop there, but don't recall this purchase)
Text: 'Congrats! You won a $1,000 Walmart gift card!' (But you didn't enter any contest)
Text: 'Reminder: Appt. with Dr. Smith tomorrow at 2 PM.' (You scheduled this appointment)
Text: 'AT&T: You're due a $75 refund for overcharges!' (But you use a different phone carrier)

sections.title: Red Flag Recap: Spotting Scams
sections.body: You've learned about several common scam tactics. Here's a quick review of the key red flags to watch out for. Tap each section for a reminder.

expandableItems.title: Red Flag: Asking for Personal Info
expandableItems.content: Unexpected texts, calls, or emails asking for sensitive details like your SSN, passwords, bank account, or credit card numbers. Legitimate companies rarely ask for this out of the blue. **Action:** Pause before sharing.

expandableItems.title: Red Flag: Pressure to Act FAST
expandableItems.content: Messages creating fake emergencies, using threats (fees, legal action, account closure), or setting super tight deadlines. Scammers want to rush you into acting without thinking. **Action:** Slow down, don't be pressured.

expandableItems.title: Red Flag: Too Good To Be True
expandableItems.content: Offers promising easy money, free luxury prizes, guaranteed high investment returns, or other unbelievable deals. If it sounds amazing but unexpected, it's likely bait. **Action:** Be skeptical.

expandableItems.title: Red Flag: Demands for Payment
expandableItems.content: Requests to pay a fee to receive a prize, send money for a supposed emergency (especially via gift card or wire), or pay unexpected bills/fines immediately. **Action:** Never pay under pressure from an unsolicited message.

expandableItems.title: Red Flag: Weird Context / Unknown Senders
expandableItems.content: Messages from numbers you don't know, or messages about accounts you don't have, orders you didn't make, or from companies you don't use. **Action:** Question it – does this make sense for *you*?

expandableItems.title: Key Action: Verify Directly & Independently
expandableItems.content: If a message seems suspicious but claims to be from a company or person you know, **do not** use any links or phone numbers *in the message*. Find the official contact info yourself (on their website, your bill, or a trusted source) and reach out directly to confirm.

quiz.question: When you get an unexpected text asking for personal info or demanding action, what's the *first* step you should always take?

options.text: Reply immediately to ask who it is or tell them to stop.
options.feedback: Replying can confirm your number is active to scammers. It's safer to pause first.

options.text: Click any links provided to see if the website looks real.
options.feedback: Clicking links in suspicious messages is risky – they could lead to fake sites or malware. Avoid clicking.

options.text: Pause, take a breath, and think before doing anything.
options.feedback: Correct! Pausing gives you time to spot red flags and decide how to proceed safely, like verifying independently.

options.text: Delete the message right away without reading it carefully.
options.feedback: While deleting scams is good, pausing to quickly assess *why* it looks like a scam helps reinforce your awareness.

quiz.question: How do scammers typically use urgency or pressure in messages?

options.text: They usually give you several days or weeks to respond.
options.feedback: That's generally the opposite of scam pressure tactics. Legitimate issues might have deadlines, but scammers create unreasonable urgency.

options.text: They create fake emergencies or tight deadlines to rush you.
options.feedback: Exactly! They want you to panic and act before you have time to think it through or verify the situation.

options.text: They suggest taking action only if it's convenient for you.
options.feedback: Scammers usually demand immediate action, not suggest waiting for your convenience.

options.text: They focus urgency only on optional 'limited-time' sales.
options.feedback: While sales have deadlines, scam urgency often involves threats about your accounts, money, or legal status.

quiz.question: Why should you be cautious with shortened links (like bit.ly) in unexpected texts?

options.text: They always contain viruses.
options.feedback: Not always, but they *can* hide dangerous links. Many legitimate services also use them, which adds to the confusion.

options.text: They mean the sender is trying to track you.
options.feedback: While link tracking exists, the main danger in scams is hiding a malicious destination.

options.text: You can't see the real web address it links to.
options.feedback: Correct! Hiding the true destination prevents you from judging if it's safe *before* clicking. It could lead anywhere – like a phishing site.

options.text: They only work for a few hours.
options.feedback: Most shortened links work for a long time unless intentionally deactivated.

quiz.question: Which request in a text message is the *clearest sign* of a scam?

options.text: Asking you to rate a recent experience.
options.feedback: While you should still be cautious with any unexpected message, legitimate businesses do ask for feedback.

options.text: Asking you to reply with your password, SSN, or bank details.
options.feedback: Absolutely! Legitimate services will *never* ask for highly sensitive info like this via text or unsolicited email.

options.text: Asking you to confirm an appointment time.
options.feedback: Appointment confirmations are common and usually legitimate if they match an appointment you actually made.

options.text: Asking you to visit their official website for more info.
options.feedback: Directing you to an official site *can* be legitimate, but always verify the link address looks correct or navigate there yourself.

quiz.question: You get a text about a delayed Amazon order, but you haven't ordered anything. This is a classic example of which red flag?

options.text: A 'too good to be true' offer.
options.feedback: This scenario isn't about an unbelievable offer; it's about a message that doesn't match your reality.

options.text: An 'out of context' or unexpected message.
options.feedback: That's right! Messages about activities you didn't do (like orders you didn't place) are a major warning sign.

options.text: A request for personal information.
options.feedback: The message itself, as described, isn't asking for info yet, though clicking a link might lead to that.

options.text: A demand for immediate payment.
options.feedback: The scenario doesn't mention payment demands, although that could be the next step if you engaged.

quiz.question: When you get a suspicious message, what's the smartest way to evaluate it?

options.text: Just check if the sender is in your contacts.
options.feedback: Scammers can fake sender info or hack accounts, so even messages from known contacts need scrutiny if they seem 'off'.

options.text: Pause, look for multiple red flags, and verify independently if unsure.
options.feedback: Yes! Pausing, checking for several warning signs (like urgency AND weird context), and verifying directly gives you the best protection.

options.text: Focus only on whether the grammar and spelling look professional.
options.feedback: Many scams look very professional now. Relying only on grammar can cause you to miss other, more important red flags.

options.text: Assume any message asking you to do anything is a scam.
options.feedback: That's too broad – many legitimate texts ask for simple actions (like confirming appointments). The key is spotting the *suspicious* elements.
